title: Riot about Annie's rework: "What we especially like is the flash+tibbers burst combo"

embed.description: Since the last update, we've thrown a couple mages into the pile beyond our original six as ones to tackle. Enclosed below is your one way ticket to Tibber’s Tea Party. Don’t miss it.

body: And that is Riot, the reason why you are so out of touch with the game and its community because flash+tibbers is what nobody likes about Annie.

replies.body: We don't think anyone likes Annie flash ulting onto them and bursting them down. We do think LoL needs some champions that provide reliable CC though as a both a balancing lever against some types of champion and as one of the ways to make short range damage focused kits functional (other options including untargetability, inherent tankiness, massive temporary defense etc). As a result we believe it's worth accepting the limited counterplay you have once Annie's in range of you, or when she has Flash up, frustrating though that can be.

Reliable CC on its own isn't necessarily a bad thing, but combined with the burst to instantly delete someone, it leans towards an unhealthy kit.

That said, champions with reliable AoE CC like this are a band-aid solution for a bigger problem.
They need to be in the game because there are champions who have too much mobility and don't have any meaningful risk built into that mobility.

You can argue that e.g. you need something like Annie's stun to deal with champions like Kalista - but I'd argue the opposite.  Champions with Kalista-levels of mobility should not exist in the first place.
A good mobility move is one with inherent risk - the champion has reasons to use it other than escaping, and it has enough cost/cooldown that they are vulnerable when they use it offensively.  Any champion with multiple dashes (or mini-cooldown dashes like Kalista/Yasuo) violate this.

There's a reason that most of the oft-complained about champions are ones capable of multiple mobility moves in a very short space of time.
Actually, people complain the most about champions that kill them. But mobility is a close second. Its why zed or graves is hated more than someone like Ahri
Maybe, but all of those champions also deal a whole lot of damage, which also fits my criteria lol {{sticker:slayer-jinx-wink}}
And when a champion has both of these things, safe mobility and lots of damage - then people will hate them even more.

I disagree.
Having less champions with extreme mobility would allow a lot more champions to be viable and increase diversity in games.

Also, playing against (and as) champions with no free escapes is far more exciting, since there's a real sense of risk and reward.
It's also more interesting to watch - one of the most well-regarded games was that UoL game where they all picked immobile champions.

The issue I have with this is that Annie's effective stun range with Flash is too large to really play around. You end up having to stay WAY off the minions if she has her stun charged, and since the buff never falls off you don't get an opportunity to just wait it out. Getting two stacks of Silver Bolts or Z-Drive Resonance sucks and means you get zoned, but at least they'll eventually fall off and you can come back to the wave. With Annie though, there's never a safe moment once she gets it charged. 

What're your thoughts on letting Pyromania fall off if Annie doesn't expend the buff in (X) seconds?

>What're your thoughts on letting Pyromania fall off if Annie doesn't expend the buff in (X) seconds?

They addressed this. It might work for laning but compromises the rest of the game. It would basically force Annie to use her abilities as spam to keep it up for initiation, and that's not a very interesting way of gating the ability. Finding something that only touches laning would be the goal.

Riot's actually done something like that with the Darius rework. His ultimate only resets itself for a few seconds after getting a kill - until he hits level 16. Then it "unlocks", fully resetting and costing zero mana to cast if he scores a kill with it. 

I see no reason Annie couldn't have a similar treatment. From levels 1-10, Pyromania has a timer on it once primed, and will fall off if an ability wasn't used in that timespan. At level 11, Annie's passive "unlocks" and remains at the ready until her next spellcast.

Sure, it's more awkward than Darius's rework and adds a bit to her burden of knowledge, but given how simple Annie currently is I'd say it's a cost she can well-afford to pay.

Edit: Whoa downvotes. Let's have a discussion about this, guys. I'm honestly curious what y'all think about adding this to Annie's kit.

Mana cost reduction is 100% for the sake of convenience. 

What you suggested totally changes her gameplay after 11.

The main issue with Annie as-is is that if she can hold her stun indefinitely, she becomes too overbearing in lane. If she can't hold her stun indefinitely, she becomes much weaker later in the game. Sure, it changes her playstyle entirely after she hits level 11, but it solves that particular problem.

I'm open to suggestions if you've got a more elegant solution. :)

No one holds the stun indefinitely, unless he has faker's level of last hitting. Among all on-demand CC, Annie sacrifices the most for it (Other being Pantheon, Lulu, Fidd, Taric, Jax who can freely cast spell and have better last hitting technique).

If you cannot stay out of her range, you are counterpicked. She's supposed to dominate glass melee. It's her niche, nothing wrong with it. I'm against all sorts of artificial intervention because rookies refuse to learn the game.
